column1: Abnormal results may be due to: - Astigmatism (abnormally curved cornea causing blurred vision) - Hyperopia (farsightedness) - Myopia (nearsightedness) - Presbyopia (inability to focus on near objects that develops with age) Other conditions under which the test may be performed: - Corneal ulcers and infections - Loss of sharp vision due to macular degeneration - Retinal detachment (separation of the light-sensitive membrane (retina) in the back of the eye from its supporting layers) - Retinal vessel occlusion (blockage in a small artery that carries blood to the retina) - Retinitis pigmentosa (damage of the retina)
After age 40 (or for people with a family history of glaucoma), eye exams should be scheduled at least once a year to test for glaucoma.
